title: Monday, 12th December, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Here we go again, then.

BE11:02am

Commenters, possibly, though none yet.

BE11:04am

Ah, there you are.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Where to begin? I guess we could take our lead from the other bastions of the Fourth Estate ..........

BE11:04am

BE11:04am

...... or maybe not.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

Instead, here's a chart.

BE11:05am

BE11:05am

That's YTD performance of the FTSE 100's top ten stocks by weight.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

A FTSE 100 tracker -- the white line -- would've done 113% (minus a fee).

BE11:06am

But if you just bought the top five stocks you'd get 124% unweighted, and 140%-ish weighted.

BE11:06am

What does this mean? Dunno.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Year of the megacaps .... Fluke on unconnected factors .... Whatever. Interesting though, right?

BE11:07am

Right?

undefined
11:07 am
BE11:08am

Sky, then. We were, in retrospect, way overcautious on Friday.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 996.25, down 3.75 (-0.38%), High: 1,003, Low: 977.00, Volume: 12.27m
BE11:08am

(@jimpj: he's in Mozambique. We assume he's coming back.)

11:08 am
BE11:09am

... because there's only ever one possible rumour with Sky, and we've heard it at least two dozen times.

BE11:09am

Including on Friday! Though it's only come true twice.

BE11:10am

Weekend press was full of Murdoch wild strategy theorising and global domination stuff.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Rubbish. He just wants the cash.

BE11:11am

Sky's in structural decline but still throwing off a lot of cash. It'll be easier for it to be in structural decline within a larger group, without 60% of its shareholders wanting a demonstrable growth strategy.

BE11:11am

Who do you want on this? I have everyone.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Citi? They're leaving the option open for a sweetener.

BE11:12am

In our view this is a low-ball bid. Our assessment of fair value for the group is consistent with £13.50 per share but we have to acknowledge that this not only assumes a relatively full valuation for the European assets (coincidentally, pretty much exactly what Sky paid for them 24 months ago) but gives the group the benefit of integration related synergies. In our most bullish scenarios (see SKY PLC (SKYB.L): Bear-Base-Bull Case Scenarios) we even see a path to nearly £18 per share. Investors, however, may well be inclined to be less generous/optimistic and, as the release, highlights: this is a 36% premium to yesterday’s close and over 40% above the close of 6 December. We think this might be enough for most investors.

BE11:12am

We expect a lot of questions on whether the group will face significant regulatory hurdles. Although we haven’t confirmed this with either company, we anticipate regulatory hurdles will be minimal. Firstly, from a competition authority perspective, Fox and Sky are not competitors in any of the markets they operate in. With the last bid process in 2010 competition approval was quickly and painlessly received and we see no reason why it would be different this time. Second, Fox is now completely separate from the previous ‘News Corp’ parent company that officially bid for BSkyB last time round. The significance of this is that Fox does not own any newspapers in the UK and therefore the transaction should raise minimal if any ‘plurality’ concerns. Even to the extent they did, it would likely require an efficient and organized campaign from the main UK opposition parties in Parliament. With a Conservative majority and other, arguably more pressing issues to deal with, we suspect this is unlikely/has a low probability of success. All in all, it may take time, but we believe the deal will face limited regulatory hurdles.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

As the release indicates, we now need to know whether Fox is happy with the terms set by the independent directors and the firm deadline for whether it is or not is the 6th January 2017. In the meanwhile it strikes us as likely that the group will trade within touching distance of the offer price (£10.75). We continue to rate the group as a Buy.

BE11:13am

And Jefferies, which was one of the champions of the structural bear case.

BE11:14am

Constraints imposed by high leverage post Europe merger have weakened Sky's standalone prospects. FOXA approach represents a welcome escape offering premium valuation (Jun17/18E: 4.1%/4.4% EFCF yield, 21.7x/17.4x PE with STBs expensed) despite the absence of competing bid interest. Crucially a better-funded Sky playing a more active role in UK BB/fibre could address Ofcom's valid competitive concerns.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Sky shares fell -17% over 4 Oct-6 Dec. With its implicit 40% premium we think the offer represents a favourable outcome for indep s/holders. Increasing concern about declining viewing figures and operational constraints imposed by high leverage (3.2x Jun17E with STBs expensed) post Europe merger have weakened confidence in Sky's standalone prospects.

BE11:15am

Addressing Ofcom's competition concerns could ease merger approval. The Takeover Code gives FOXA until 5pm on 6 Jan to announce a firm intention to make an offer. Govt then has 10 days to refer to Ofcom. Ofcom's historic reservations about media plurality seem less credible now with more fragmented landscapes of news distribution and TV, also the split of legacy News Corp TV and press interests. FOXA's promise that a merger would secure the UK's position as a major hub for content generation and technological innovation may please Ofcom. But FOXA could also position the merger to address 'competition concerns' that Ofcom stressed heavily in its 6 Dec consultation on physical infrastructure access. Currently BT/Virgin dominate the retail hi-speed BB mkt with c.80% combined share. FOXA could commit that Sky would return to a more active role in BB (de-emphasised last 3 qtrs) and even commit to limited 'full fibre' investments.

BE11:15am

Creating a more robust challenger to BT. A key weakness of Sky in recent years has been its inability to pursue the full range of its commercial opportunities. This has eased BT's entry into TV and restricted Sky's disruptive actions with BB and NOW TV. Integrated into a larger FOXA group, Sky could become a much tougher competitor for BT, with the 1Q17 Champions League rights auction a first test.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

And from the Fox perspective, Credit Suisse.

BE11:16am

Accretive to EPS but dilutive to growth: 82% of Sky's EBITDA is in the U.K., where competition in pay TV, broadband and wireless is fierce; Netflix penetration is still low; and where sports rights are renewed in three year cycles. We also note that the EPL has far more global appeal than the NFL, NBA and MLB, making it more attractive to digital distributors like Amazon and therefore adding to potential rights cost inflation for Sky's largest single programming cost line. We believe FOXA will need to demonstrate to shareholders why the acquisition won't be dilutive to the company's long term growth as a result of this transaction - this may be dependent on unlocking revenue synergies from the new company, which given high levels of cooperation between the companies historically may be difficult to achieve.

BE11:16am

Ofcom approval needed for license transfers: The potential deal is subject to material conditions; and, if formalized, will be subject to shareholder and U.K./ European antitrust approval. Additionally, because Sky's channels operate under licenses granted by U.K. regulator Ofcom, the transfer of these licenses to FOXA will also be subject to Ofcom approval. We do not anticipate this being a barrier to the deal but note that licensees must be deemed "fit and proper" by Ofcom.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

I'm getting bored now. One more?

BE11:18am

Berenberg.

BE11:19am

While BSkyB is now called Sky (following its acquisition of Fox’s Italian and German assets) and the bidder this time is Fox, rather than News Corp, no one should be under any illusion that this is a re-run of the same deal: a Murdoch-controlled entity bidding for Europe’s largest pay-tv business.
● Public interest test probably satisfied: In 2010, OFCOM concluded that the proposed acquisition might operate against the public interest on plurality grounds. Subsequently, however, a structure was posited that would have seen News Corp spin off Sky News into a separate company. We suspect that similar conditions might be placed on Fox/Sky, even if it is News Corp, not Fox, that publishes newspapers: the reality is that both companies are controlled by the same family.
● Fit and proper test could raise issues: Following the phone hacking scandal, while OFCOM concluded that BSkyB was a fit and proper company to hold a broadcasting licence, it was highly critical of James Murdoch’s conduct. This was, however, mitigated by the fact that there were other directors or shareholders. With Sky now set to be fully owned by Fox (and thus the Murdochs), the question may be raised again. The Leveson inquiry was very critical of News Corp’s management.
● A different political climate: Potentially the biggest issue, though, is political. David Cameron was seen as sympathetic to the Murdochs, while Theresa May will likely wish to be seen as not being in the hands of big corporates. The culture secretary, Karen Bradley, is an unknown quantity, having come from a different ministry, while Sharon White, head of OFCOM, has been taking a tough line with companies that are not driving benefits for consumers.
● Fox wants direct access to consumers: We think the primary rationale for the deal is access to customers. Media distribution has changed hugely since 2010, and it is the rise of Netflix, Amazon Prime and other over-thetop services that is driving this deal, we believe. It helps, of course, that Sky has de-rated substantially following investor concern about quality and predictability of earnings. We do not see any other bidder, but suspect that this deal will take quite some time to clear. We upgrade Sky to Hold on the basis that the deal will ultimately clear, with conditions, at 1,075p.

11:19 am
undefined
BE11:20am

Meanwhile, in the busted-flush M&A category .......

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 120.30, down 10.3 (-7.89%), High: 125.20, Low: 120.20, Volume: 8.61m
11:20 am
BE11:21am

This caused some fun and games on Friday afternoon ......

GVC Holdings PLC (GVC:LSE): Last: 637.00, up 2 (+0.31%), High: 639.00, Low: 630.50, Volume: 181.83k
BE11:21am

..... to recap: https://www.ft.com...-8b45-b8b81dd5d080

11:21 am
BE11:22am

And then, slightly later: https://www.ft.com...-8e58-880af1f9dae3

BE11:22am

No statement from either company, as you'd expect.

BE11:23am

And lots of present-tense denials from Feltcollaredsource familiar with the situation as we headed towards press time on Friday night.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Now, the idea being put around this morning is that GVC went pens down when it became clear that the story had leaked .....

BE11:25am

(Sunday Times, us and Bloomberg were all chasing the same info. Perhaps more.)

BE11:25am

.......... And as I understand it, avoiding any kind of statement means GVC isn't locked in by the six-month Takeover Panel bar.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

So might try and resurrect this.

BE11:26am

I stress, might.

BE11:27am

The price going around the market on Friday was around 170p -- which isn't a blistering premium for what promised to be an extremely difficult mostly-equity-funded deal to put together.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Still, that's all archaeology now.

BE11:27am

Coincidentally, Goldman has a big note out on the bookies this morning.

BE11:27am

Pushing Ladbrokes, among others.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Strong online growth continues; share gains in focus
We expect the UK gaming market to continue to progressively shift online (from 53% of rev. in 2015 to 62% in 2019E). This, combined with a market growing above nominal consumer spending, means we forecast an 11% online revenue CAGR 2016-19E for the market. Further, concentration has increased (HHI of top 6: 606 in 2013 to 1,234 in 2016PF) while the pace of channel shift has moderated slightly, increasing the importance of online share gains for sustainably high earnings growth, in our view.

BE11:28am

( ROTR:

BE11:28am

11:29 am
BE11:29am

(... heh, seems it doesn't work over there. Never mind.)

BE11:30am

We expect operators’ online growth trajectories to differ significantly. We forecast online growth rates based primarily on the size and effectiveness of marketing spend and operators’ ability to retain existing customers (a reflection of product breadth and quality). We expect Ladbrokes Coral to be the biggest market share winner (+1.9pp pa 2016-18E) given the size of its
marketing budget (1.5x WMH’s, 0.8x PPB’s) and efficiency of its spend (2016E cost/acquisition 46% less than WMH, 17% less than PPB).

BE11:30am

An ongoing UK government review of gaming machines and advertising could lead to increased regulation; gaming machines are c.6%-30% of UK bookmaker revenues. That said, we estimate a maximum machine stake cut to £50 (from £100) would reduce 2017E EPS by 8% for LCL, 4% for WMH, and 1% PPB, while the stocks have de-rated 15% (12m fwd P/E) over the past month.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

We forecast a 16% CY17-19 online revenue CAGR for LCL vs. 9% for WMH. We see LCL’s CY17E EV/EBIT of 11.0x as attractive vs. WMH 10.7x. We reinstate our rating on LCL at Buy; our 12m SOTP-based PT of 170p (CY18E) implies 38% upside; the CY18E P/E is c.12x at our PT, 1x below WMH’s average over the last 3 years. Our WMH 12m PT is now 300p (based on CY18E SOTP, with a 15% M&A weighting), implying 2% upside; down to Sell.

William Hill PLC (WMH:LSE): Last: 289.00, down 1.3 (-0.45%), High: 291.00, Low: 285.00, Volume: 932.91k

agreed

BE11:32am

BE11:02am

Markets Live. FT Alphaville. Typing. Numbers. Grey bumf. Stuff.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Read this instead: https://www.ft.com...-ba85-95d1533d9a62

undefined
BE11:36am

Back to London .................

11:36 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 341.30, up 2.7 (+0.80%), High: 354.70, Low: 340.60, Volume: 4.40m
BE11:37am

Merrill positive.

BE11:37am

It's a bit of a turnaround thesis, albeit an unambitious one.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Upgrade to Buy, PO raised to 400p, 21% upside. While not blind to the challenges M&S faces, we believe consensus is too pessimistic on 2018 where we forecast positive LfL’s in Clothing & Home (compared to consensus at - 2%) as we believe easy prior year comparisons, an aggressive approach to pricing and a rejuvenated product range can all serve to support growth. On the food side of the business we expect to see continued market share gains and believe M&S could be in an ideal situation to benefit from modest FX driven inflation and actually benefit from the increase in the living wage given its geographic footprint. Combined this leaves our EPS forecast for 2018 c.5% ahead of consensus and with shares offering an underlying 10% FCF yield and trading at 10.6x 2018E P/E (vs a 10 year average of 12x) we have raised our PO to 400p.

BE11:38am

Gross margins more insulated from FX than peers We believe M&S has lost 200-400bp of potential gross margin between 2012 and 2016 due to markdown and discounting. We believe this represents a significant opportunity to improve margins and should provide a degree of insulation from the FX pressures we expect the apparel market to face in 2017. While M&S is giving away some of this by adopting an everyday low price point we believe they are better placed than peers to manage cost inflation and assume only 30bps of gross margin deterioration in Clothing and Home in 2018E (vs consensus of 43bps).

BE11:39am

Improving cash generation under-appreciated We believe consensus still underestimates the cash generation of M&S with a new strict approach towards capex and a likely improving working capital profile as the business mix shifts towards food. We also note an organisation which has historically underplayed the potential for cost cutting and wonder if there could be further upside to the cost savings announced (£45m from International and £30m from UK head office).

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Some mildly interesting charts in there ...........

BE11:39am

BE11:40am

Having 25% of the 55+ clothes market must be worth something, right? There's a margin in cardigans.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

.... Merrill also pushing Dixons, since we're here.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 360.30, up 0.1 (+0.03%), High: 368.90, Low: 360.30, Volume: 1.59m
BE11:41am

Upgrade to Buy PO raised to 470p, 37% upside potential The potential for market share gains, new contract wins and signs of a rational competitive environment in 2017 provide us confidence that DC can navigate the pressures posed by heavy reliance on USD denominated products and a likely tougher consumer environment in the coming twelve-months. In light of this we believe the investor focus can shift back to the positive mid-term investment case as DC continues to build its Connect World Services (CWS) and services business as well as the potential for accretive M&A. Ultimately we see 3% upside to consensus EPS in 2017 and 4% downside in 2018 but with shares trading at 11x 2018E P/E (2013-2015 average 15.2x) we believe the downside risks are well understood by the market and see 37% upside potential.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

2017 estimates supported by Argos, iPhone 7 and CWS We see three key revenue drivers which could support estimates into 2017: 1) We expect Argos to lose c.15% of revenues as its store estate is combined with Sainsbury’s. Assuming DC can win its market share of this lost revenue then we believe this should give DC LfLs a c.1% boost; 2) We believe the iPhone 7 has supported growth 2H 2016; and 3) we believe there is potential for DC to announce some new CWS contract wins fuelling the structural story of moving to a services based business model.

BE11:42am

Sanguine on the risks in 2017 We take a cautious view on the UK consumer in CY2017 as inflation saps consumer enthusiasm for big ticket purchases. Nonetheless, we are more sanguine on these risks than a few months ago with the competitive environment looking more rational.

BE11:43am

Outside chance of MMS deal could provide upside While we ascribe no value to it happening, our calculations indicate the speculated combination of Media Markt Saturn’s electronics business and DC has the potential to drive shareholder value (Telegraph 13/08/16). If a merger were to happen, we calculate it is possible DC shareholders could receive a c.4% special dividend and EPS accretion of c.47% in 2020E. Should DC acquire MMS outright then we calculate 119% potential EPS accretion in 2020.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(Don't remember the Media Markt story. Someone can remind me I'm sure.)

undefined
BE11:45am

@Dust, on Stada, we've heard nothing new.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

SonntagsZeitung picked up on the Novartis theory, though it's not clear whether they were just regurgitating stale rumours.

BE11:45am

http://www.sonntag...mahersteller-80500

BE11:47am

To reiterate what we've already said, we heard Mylan was the predator at a price in the high 50s but was told "not interested" and that was that.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

But that's RAW. And probably stale raw.

BE11:48am

BE11:49am

11:49 am
Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 227.80, up 15.2 (+7.15%), High: 228.60, Low: 214.50, Volume: 1.10m
BE11:49am

Did I see it on Canaccord's 2017 picks?

BE11:50am

..... No.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The European Select list is intended to be an evergreen selection, regularly updated. With this note we are adding Amec F-W, Coats, Ithaca, JLT Group, Lookers, McCarthy & Stone, and Zoopla, and removing Consort Medical, Just Eat, Petra Diamonds and Provident.

BE11:51am

BE11:52am

Nope. Sorry. Clueless on Mitie. Asking around. If you know, do give me a shout.

11:51 am
undefined
BE11:52am

Into smalls, there's the E2V bid.

BE11:53am

Cash offer from Teledyne Technologies.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Shares up 47% at 272.3p in the middle, suggesting it's done.

BE11:53am

Here's Cantor.

BE11:53am

Teledyne has offered 275p per share, representing a 48% premium to Friday’s close of 185.5p. Teledyne’s Board believes that there is a highly complementary fit between the two businesses and this should enable both companies to accelerate revenue growth across a range of multiple industrial markets. We previously had a TP of 290p and a BUY recommendation on e2v, based on a growing pipeline of opportunities, particularly in professional imaging, radiotherapy and the space exploration markets. Given the niche operations of e2v, we do not believe that there will be a counterbid or that competition authorities will block the transaction. We reiterate our BUY and place our TP under review from 290p.

· Valuation and risks – The 275p offer values e2v at £619m and places is on a prospective 12 month PER of c.19x and EV/EBITDA of c.11x. Principal risks for e2v are cyclicality in end markets, currency impact, acquisition risk and lumpy contracts.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

And Liberum.

BE11:54am

This represents a 48% premium to the closing price on Friday and a 10% premium to the September high. It values the business on a March 17 P/E of 20x. We recently cut FY adj EPS by 10% following the H1 warning. There remained a steep hill to climb in H2 (H2 eps bias is 74% vs 62% 4yr av) and so this will come as a relief. The e2v Directors consider the terms to be fair and reasonable. The market will scan for other niche, high tech industrials that have endured a bumpy ride and could look appealing to large US industrials - Oxford Instruments (Hold, TP 690p) may look like a tasty morsel.

Oxford Instruments PLC (OXIG:LSE): Last: 672.13, up 0.625 (+0.09%), High: 672.13, Low: 666.50, Volume: 6.36k
11:54 am
undefined
BE11:56am

Mondays are the worst, right? I think I've run out of momentum.

BE11:56am

I mean, there's always sellside to fill the space.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Such as on gold, or more specifically on Polymetal.

Polymetal International PLC (POLY:LSE): Last: 745.00, down 38 (-4.85%), High: 786.50, Low: 737.00, Volume: 1.36m
BE11:57am

As well as the obvious, it's also suffering from an RBC downgrade.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Polymetal remains an industry-leading precious metals company. Arguably no company has done more through the downturn to add value via strategic M&A. However, with increasing gold price volatility, high levels of 2017 capex and a higher FCF breakeven price than peers we downgrade to Sector Perform.

BE11:58am

Gold price volatility tightens financial flexibility in 2017
Following POLY's counter-cyclical acquisitions through the downturn, the company has generated numerous growth options largely via value-additive resource acquisitions. This is driving, on our estimates, a 7% (2015-2020) production CAGR whilst adding lower-than-average costs. We see the potential beyond our current forecasts as robust considering POLY's key competitive advantage of monetising stranded Russian refractory gold deposits. However, with this production growth comes significant capex with 2017 likely to be the peak year for capex spending at Kyzyl. Additionally, POLY's net debt to EBITDA at FY16E 1.8x could erode rapidly in a lower gold price environment. Without changing current capex plans (and after cancelling dividends) we calculate POLY to be cash breakeven in 2017 at $1,125/oz.

BE11:58am

Breakeven of $1,125 is quite high, no? It's a long time since I've looked at the sector properly, but that sounds high.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The recovery in oil prices is likely to relieve some of the pressure on the Russian economy. This is likely a positive around the potential for tax pressure but will also reduce some of the cost benefit that POLY has received since 2014, as the ruble is down ~50% since then. We expect a modest strengthening of the RUB over the coming 24 months. We expect POLY will maintain strong cost control (and forecast AISC $764/oz in 2017); however, the cost environment may not be as conducive going forward on a relative basis.

BE11:59am

Although we see the potential for more pressure on precious metals prices in the near term, we do expect that through 2017 there is upside risk to inflation concerns and this should be very positive for gold, eventually. On our base case $1,300/oz POLY still generates a 10% FCF making the valuation attractive. We also expect that POLY will have the ability to navigate any financial pressure through 2017. However, we see the potential for the multiple to further erode (as it has done through Q4 2016). We move our 12-month target multiples to 1.0x NAV and 9x P/CF (down from 1.3x and 14x, respectively) driving an 810p target price. We downgrade POLY to Sector Perform whilst gold transitions through this volatile phase.

BE11:59am

Our target price is based on multiples of 1.0x P/NAV and 9x P/adj CF on our blended 2017 estimates, which generate an 810p price target, and therefore we rate the stock Sector Perform. These multiples are on the lower end of the global Tier II group averages due to higher development risk and geopolitical risk perceptions.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Meanwhile, want some TA on gold?

BE12:00pm

Of course you don't! Yet brokers continue to produce it, much as newspapers continue to print horoscopes.

BE12:00pm

Here's Natixis.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

BE12:01pm

What does this mean?

BE12:01pm

Literally nothing.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

"We recommend being vigilant by keeping a lookout at 1145"
Thumbs up

BE12:02pm

I'll do that. Ta for the advice.

undefined
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

And ..... we're done. That's midday.

BE12:03pm

Oh, seems Bloomberg moved a Stada story when we were looking elsewhere.

BE12:03pm

Bloomberg reports that Stada's time as an independent drugmaker may be drawing to a close, as it has attracted interest from several private equity firms including Permira, CVC Capital Partners and Bain Capital. Cites people familiar with the matter as saying buyout firms have been studying the feasibility of a takeover with potential advisers, although deliberations are at an early stage. Adds that rival generics companies have also informally looked at the company. Notes however, that while Stada is working with its long-time adviser Perella Weinberg on strategy, the company isn’t running a sales process and is currently more focused on improving operations, although it is open to playing a role in the industry’s consolidation.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

OK. There we are. Seems a bit weedy.

BE12:04pm

Okay, let's close. Thanks for bearing with.

BE12:05pm

Back tomorrow, unless I can think of an excuse not to be.

12:04 pm
BE12:05pm

See you then. Afternoon all.

BE11:35am

Hm. I started that theme then realised I have literally nothing to say about it.
